awd_titl_txt: GOALI: An Experimental Study of Electric Field Driven Non-Fourier Thermal Transport in High Power Electronic Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Featuring broadband operation and high efficiency, gallium nitride-based radio frequency power amplifiers are key components to realize reliable, energy efficient, and ubiquitous wireless 5G networks that billions of devices use for data collection and computation. However, full implementation of gallium nitride microelectronics for 5G wireless networks requires overcoming concerns about overheating. This project will investigate and identify the thermal transport mechanisms leading to the discrepancies between theoretical predictions and experimental observations, to allow design of effective thermal management for reliable performance. Moreover, this project will encompass educational tasks designed to bridge the gap between thermal sciences and electronic device physics and to lower the entry barrier for undergraduate students to study nanoscale heat transfer principles. The educational activities will also expose underrepresented students to industry-driven academic research and inspire K-12 students to pursue STEM-related fields.

The research goal of this project is to experimentally identify and probe nanoscopic, non-Fourier thermal transport mechanisms that are responsible for the amplified heating within gallium nitride transistors simultaneously subjected to extreme electric field and heat flux conditions. It is hypothesized that the observed amplified heating is a combined result of nanoscale heat source size effects, electric field induced deformation of the gallium nitride crystal, and thermal non-equilibrium among energy carriers, all of which are caused by a nanoscale electric field spike. A deep ultraviolet thermal imaging capability which offers the highest spatial resolution among commercial thermal imaging systems will be developed in order to test this hypothesis and to study the fundamental physics in gallium nitride transistors. The developed deep ultraviolet thermal imaging technique will be used together with Raman spectroscopy, photoluminescence, and a novel multi-scale electro-thermal modeling scheme to study the physical origins of the amplified heating in high voltage-biased gallium nitride transistors. Research outcomes will facilitate electro-thermal co-design and improve industry standard methods for lifetime assessment of gallium nitride power amplifiers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Wide bandgap semiconductor devices are key components that are necessary to realize next generation wireless communication and electrified propulsion systems. However, the demanding service conditions for these devices pose thermal reliability concerns. The academic goal of this project was to experimentally identify and probe the amplified self-heating within wide bandgap semiconductor devices caused by electric field concentration and non-Fourier thermal transport. The industrial goal of the project was to leverage the expertise of Microsanj and Penn State to co-develop a deep-ultraviolet thermoreflectance thermal imaging capability that offers a higher (up to 100X) spatial resolution than today's commercial thermal imaging systems.

This advanced optical thermography technique was used to study electro-thermal interactions that govern the self-heating behavior of state-of-the-art electronic devices based on wide bandgap semiconductors including GaN and Ga2O3. GaN based radio frequency (RF) power amplifiers are currently supporting the 5G wireless infrastructure, while ultra-wide bandgap Ga2O3devices are under development to construct next generation RF and power conversion devices. Spatial and temporal aspects of phonon transport within these structures were studied to understand the steady-state and transient device self-heating behavior. For example, under a partially pinched-off condition, GaN transistors would exhibit a nanoscopic confinement of the Joule heat generation that results in emergence of a hotspot that is hotter than predictions based on macroscale heat transfer principles (i.e., Fourier’s law of heat conduction). It was demonstrated that the ultraviolet thermoreflectance imaging technique can be used with standard wafer level electrical test structures to perform nondestructive thermo-physical property measurement. Based on experimental and computational analysis of thermally resistive components within GaN and Ga2O3 device material stacks, electro-thermal co-design strategies were established to overcome the severe overheating in wide bandgap semiconductor devices. For instance, through multi-university-industry collaboration, a device-level thermal management solution that would mitigate self-heating in a Ga2O3 transistor device was demonstrated by substrate heterogeneous integration and top-side heat extraction using a polycrystalline diamond heat spreader. 

The fundamental knowledge obtained from this project will allow device engineers to construct thermally aware device structures that overcome overheating concerns associated with high power wide bandgap semiconductor devices used in future radio frequency (RF) communication and power conversion applications. The research outcomes were published in more than nineteen conference and journal articles. At several international conferences, the research findings were used to educate thermal and device engineers in industry about the need for electro-thermal co-design. Students working on this project were able to conduct research and gain experience in an industrial setting by collaborating with Microsanj. In addition, a minority graduate student has participated in producing these research outcomes.  These research findings were used to modernize a heat transfer course taught at Penn State by exposing students to the latest device technologies that require proper thermal management. Educational outreach activities were performed at regional K-12 public schools via the development of an educational infrared thermography kit.

The fundamental knowledge and research outcomes of this project will improve the reliability of next-generation radio frequency (RF) power amplifiers and power conversion devices. The transformative impact of this work will be to facilitate the electro-thermal co-design of next-generation radar systems, power converters for renewable energy sources, inverters for electric vehicles, and smart grid technology. The societal impact will be to contribute to the realization of a reliable, energy efficient, and ubiquitous wireless 5G/6G network that integrates data collection and computation with billions of devices. 

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2024
Modified by: Sukwon Choi
